titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Had no sleep the last Night— Rose very early and went to the tavern— Return’d to Mr Townsend’s to breakfast— We tried the question upon the Will, to the Court— Mr: Parsons and Mr: Dexter against Mr: Ames and me— But we could prove nothing, and the Will was established— Just as the Judgment of the Court was recording, I received a note from W. Shaw, with information that the house of Bird Savage and Bird in London, has failed— I stayed only at dinner, with the Judges and immediately after sat out to return home— Overtook Mr: J. S. Williams who was on foot, walking home to Roxbury. Took him into the Chaise with me and left him at his lodgings— On arriving in town, I received by the mail from New-York, a circular letter from the House of Bird, Savage and Bird dated 7. Feby: giving notice of their suspension of payments—with the addition, that they would endeavour to get some house to take up my bills upon them—on which however I place not the least dependence. The property they have in their hands is my father’s; but I must provide for taking the bills up, which I had drawn— For this purpose I have no other means than to sell my own property— I call’d upon Mr: Smith to ask him if he wish’d to purchase again the house I bought of him, and in which I now live, but he said it would not be convenient— I have never before met so severe a shock in respect to property as this— Pass’d the evening with the Society; but Mr: Emerson was absent and gave us no exhibition.

2. This morning I applied to Mr: Jackson the broker, to sell my fire and marine insurance company shares and those of my father; for the purpose of raising money to defray the bills which must return upon my hands; he was unable to sell them however this day. Mr: Freeman called upon me with one of the bills, that for £400—protested—12 Feby:—two days later than the letter of Bird Savage and Bird to me— So they were unable to procure any house to take them up— And I must expect them all back within a few days— I paid Mr: Freeman for his bill with all the charges—which are lighter than I can expect they will be upon any of the rest.— In the afternoon I wrote to my brother, to prepare him for the return of the bill I sent him last Novr: and to promise him it shall immediately be paid.— I went out to Quincy with Mr: J. Gardner, in the Evening, and had the task to perform of giving notice to my father and mother of this misfortune:
they felt it severely; but bore it with proper firmness and composure— I feel myself in a great degree answerable for this calamity, and of course bound to share largely in the loss— The business of drawing the money from Holland was entrusted to me; and I adopted a method of transacting it, which has failed— The error of judgment was mine, and therefore I shall not refuse to share in the suffering—

3. Heard Mr: Whitney— Employed the remainder of the day in transcribing and correcting part of the translation of the Oration de Socrate Cive— It served in some small degree to abstract my mind from the subject which presses heavily upon it— I made some arrangement with my father, to dispose of his stocks and my own, to discharge the returning bills; and for my removal from Boston, where I can no longer support the expence of residing, after what has happened.

4. Return’d to Boston this morning— Mr: Jackson has not been able to sell my Insurance Company Shares— I spoke with Coll: Bradford, to sell at auction my House in Franklin-place, the 13th: instt:— Wrote to Coll: Smith, and to Mr: R. Bird at New-York.— The Election of Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Senators was this day made— The federal ticket prevailed—the numbers about 1680 to 1050—the number of voters of course much smaller than last year— I spent the Evening at home, reading part of As you like it to the Ladies.

5. Day at my Office— Gave Coll: Bradford an advertisement for the sale of my house in Franklin-Place— Mr: Quincy offered me an accommodation to take $5000 dollars from the Union Bank if I should find it necessary.— Mr: Smith also offered me any assistance of lending his name in case I should want it, to borrow money, for taking up my bills, untill I can sell property to discharge them— This evening there was a very numerous company, and a Ball at Mr: Mason’s— I went with Caroline, but as Mrs: Adams could not go, I return’d home immediately; leaving Caroline to come home with Mrs: Quincy— In a New-York newspaper of 31. March is an advertisement, calling a meeting of the creditors of Robert Bird, that evening.
6. Forenoon at my Office, reading assiduously— The carriage came into Boston, and after dinner, I went out with Mrs: Adams, Caroline and the child to Quincy— Mrs: Adams was unwell.
7. Fast day— Heard Mr: Whitney— Walk in the afternoon with my father over the hill— Spent the remnant of the day in copying off, from Luzac’s Oration—

8. Return’d to Boston this morning, with Mr: Black; leaving the ladies and George, at Quincy. Meeting of the Committee of Directors of Neponsit Bridge, at my Office. Agreed with Coll: Warner, to act as our Overseer— Received a letter from Bird Savage and Bird dated 25 Feby:— Mr: King had agreed to take up most of my bills— Evening at the Society— Dr: Warren exhibited a number of experiments— Had a violent thunder shower, while there.

9. The accounts I receive, as to the affairs of Bird, Savage and Bird, are very unpromising— This day brought me a letter from my brother, enclosing a protest for better security upon the bill he negotiated for me last Winter— The protest was made after acceptance and before the day of payment— This Evening I went out to Quincy— Found Mrs: Adams unwell.

10. Mrs: Adams very unwell with a severe head-ache the whole day.— Heard Mr: Whitney. All my leisure employed in transcribing and reading at the Office— Consulted Warton’s History of English Poetry— Mrs: Bass, my old School mistress dined with us.

11. We all return’d to town this morning, and though Mrs: Adams was still unwell, went to the play this Evening—to Mrs: Darley’s benefit— Saw Much ado about Nothing—And the Shakespeare Jubilee— The performance of the first was better than I expected— House very full.

12. Mrs: Adams very ill again this morning; but the latter part of the day somewhat recovered. I went alone to Cambridge, and attended the examination of the Senior Sophister Class, as chairman of the Committee of Overseers— The examination took up the whole day; every member of the class being successively interrogated by the tutors and professors— Upon History, Natural Philosophy, Metaphysics, Mathematics, Belles Lettres and Composition, and lastly Theology— There were also read Themes written on two subjects— One text “Faults in the life, breed errors in the brain”—the other, “Homo sum, nil humani a me alienum puto”— Just before dinner Mr: Wendell, a member of the corporation intimated to me that as chairman of the Overseers, it was my duty, when the examination should be finished to make a short address to the Students, expressive of our approbation, and encouraging them in the pursuit of their studies— This being altogether new and unexpected to me somewhat disconcerted me, and I requested Mr: Ames to perform the task in my stead— Which however he peremptorily refused— I therefore made the address, supplying by its brevity for all its deficiencies— We dined at the Steward’s— The chairman of the Committee of Overseers likewise presides there— After the examination was finished, we took tea at President Willard’s— Judge Davis’s return’d to town with me. I found Mrs: Adams much better than in the morning, though still unwell— Caroline spent the Evening out— At Miss Allen’s.— George 2 years old— Measures 2 feet 8 inches 7/10

13. Walk this morning before Breakfast— Spent the day at my Office— Heavily— Club this Evening at Mr: Emerson’s— Mr: B. Pickman this day told me that he had about 10,000 dollars in the hands of Mr: S. Williams in London, which would be at my disposal for the payment of my bills there, if it would suit my convenience. I notice this obliging offer, as I wish never to forget any service or even tender of service, on an occasion of difficulty and embarrassment like that in which I am now placed— It may perhaps be advantageous to me to accept of Mr: Pickman’s offer.

14. At my Office, the whole day— Variety of people upon business in the forenoon. Sold my house in Franklin-Place N: 13. at Auction, by Coll: Bradford.— It was purchased by Mr: John Brazer, for 7175 dollars. 5 per cent paid; and the remainder the 1st: of August next— I pass’d the evening at home with the ladies, and finished reading “As you like it.”

15. Saw Mr: Quincy this morning, and endeavoured to settle with him, Mr: Murray’s affair with the directors of the Union Bank. But in vain— They frighten Murray almost out of his wits— I encourage him as well as I can— Evening at the Society— Dr: Warren exhibited a variety of experiments on the combinations of oxygen and azote.— Had a Severe Snow-storm.

16. Meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge this forenoon at my Office— Only Mr: Smith and Mr: Quincy there— The Gentlemen from Quincy did not come into town, owing probably to the badness of the weather— The Snow-storm continued all last night— This day the ground is covered with snow, and the sleighs were about as in mid-winter— Dined at Mr: Smith’s. Mr: Quincy likewise there— Evening at home— Caroline pass’d it, at Mrs: W. Sullivan’s.— At the Meeting of the directors this morning, as our treasurer was not in town, we paid Messrs: Crane and Upham for the timber they have delivered according to contract.

17. Heard Mr: Green, for Mr: Emerson the whole day. Wrote a letter to my brother— Evening at home writing— The Snow-storm is not yet over— Snow’d at times the greater part of this day— Thaws at the same time; which makes the passing in the Streets very bad— I could scarcely get to and from the post-office.

18. The Snow is disappearing; but the streets so bad I could not walk much. Day at my Office, reading— Letter from my brother— Evening at home— Began reading to the Ladies Robertson’s History of America— Mr: Jos: Hall, pass’d part of the Evening and supp’d with us.

19. Meeting of the Directors of Neponsit Bridge, at my Office.— Directed an assessment of $20 on each share, to be paid the first of June. Coll: Warner was with us— Mr: Quincy and Mr: Beale went out after dinner to look at the Salem turnpike at Lynn— I pass’d the day at my Office, and the Evening at home— Finish’d reading the first Chapter of Robertson’s History of America— Which is but Introductory— Read also this afternoon several chapters of Montaigne’s Essays— He imitates the manner of Plutarque— Walk’d at the beginning of the Evening in the Mall.

20. The weather again suffers me to walk; but I cannot make due application to my business— Pass’d the day at my Office— Mr: Gurley, in Treaty with me for my house in Court-Street— Club this evening at Mr: Kirkland’s. Received letters from Coll: Smith and from R. Bird at New-York.

21. Wrote to Mr: S. Williams, in London, requesting him to manage my demands against Bird, Savage, and Bird— Day at my Office— Reading Kyd, and Montague— Mrs: Adams continues very unwell, with a severe cough— Was bled this afternoon— Read in the Evening in Robertson, the account of the first voyage of Columbus, his discovery of St. Salvador or Guanahani, Cuba, and Hispaniola.

22. Reading Kyd, and Montaigne’s Essays— That upon the Education of children seizes my attention more forcibly, than any of its predecessors— In the Evening, met with the Society— Dr: Warren’s lecture was upon the properties of hydrogen gas; and the composition of water by its combination with oxygen.

23. My mother came to town this morning with Louisa Smith and Susan. Mr: Gardner also called, and dined with us— I went out with him, and Mr: Shaw, with my mother— Stop’d at Milton, and walk’d with Mr: Gardner to Quincy— He went with me the greater part of the way— In the evening, I was unexpectedly unwell, and obliged to retire to bed— Mrs: Adams still continues, far from well.

24. Heard Mr: Bowes Whitney, the day through— Most of my time was employed in the drudgery of copying.— Translated also a stanza of Rousseau’s Ode to Fortune— I have now here little leisure to read— Not very well this day.

25. Mr: S. Spear this morning— Return’d to Boston with Mr: Shaw— Found Mrs: Adams better, though not fully recovered; Received letters from Bird, Savage and Bird, by the Galen—11. March, with my Account— Also a letter from Mr: Samuel
Samuel Williams, informing me, that he with Mr: King and Mr: Gore, had agreed to take up for my honour my bills, on Bird, Savage and Bird, accepted by them and protested for non-payment.— I called at the Union Bank to see if I could arrange Mr: Murray’s business, and was told I had overdrawn there on my own account. It was by a check I had given a month before they drew my last balance; but not presented untill afterwards. I paid them immediately the amount of what I had overdrawn— In the afternoon I wrote to Mr: B. Pickman junr: to enquire if he could let me have bills on S. Williams, as he offered me last week; to repay him his advances. Evening at home, reading, in the first volume of Robertson.

26. Sent by Mr: T. Williams the letter I wrote yesterday to Mr: Pickman— Court of Common-Pleas in Session. Drew up an engagement for Mr: Murray to sign to the President and Directors of the Union Bank. Mr: Quincy took it, and said he believed it would do— I examined a question of Law, with Mr: Gurley.— Evening at home reading Robertson.

27. Went to Dedham this morning— Stop’d on the way at Mr: Boylston’s in Roxbury to take his papers— Settled the two Actions I had at the Common Pleas sitting there, and return’d home to dinner— Afternoon at my Office— Mr: Gurley there— Received an answer from Mr: B. Pickman, that he will let me have bills upon Mr: Williams— Evening with the Club at Mr: Quincy’s— Meeting thin, the weather being very bad.

28. Tried the Cause of Fenno vs Harris at the Common Pleas— Thurston for Harris— Verdict for Fenno, his whole demand— Mr: Pickman called upon me, and furnished me a bill at 10 days sight on Mr: Williams, for £1850, and engaged to furnish me with one for £1020 more, when I call for it— For the present bill, I give 2 1/2 per ct: advance the current rate of exchange— He took my note upon interest payable in six calendar months— Mrs: Adams very ill this afternoon.— Evening at home— Finished reading the first volume of Robertson’s History of America.

29. Mrs: Adams continues very ill with pains in her hand and arm similar to those she suffered formerly on like occasions— Principal part of the day at my Office— A Short time at Court— And attended a Bar-meeting. Evening at the Society’s meeting— Dr: Warren read us a lecture and shewed some experiments upon Water— This was the last meeting for the Season, and in Mr: Emerson’s house— A Committee was empowered to procure a room, and to call a meeting when they shall have succeeded in the search.

30. Sudden change of weather from cold to warm— Forenoon at my Office— Writing to Mr: S. Williams— In the afternoon, I set out to walk to Quincy; but met Dexter, with the chaise upon the neck— Went the rest of the way with him— Mr: T. C. Amory, and Mr: W. Sullivan overtook me, and stop’d to give me some papers, of a Commission for taking a deposition—From the Supreme Court at New-York.— Reach’d Quincy early.

Day— Rise, between 6 and 8 without any regularity— Read or write untill 10. breakfast— Pass the rest of the forenoon at my Office—And usually the afternoon—Untill 7.— Walk an hour— Remainder of the Evening, excepting those appropriated to the Club and the Society, at home, reading to the ladies— Sundays almost always at Quincy; generally much engaged in writing.
